Subject: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit

Hello.

I am a happy and satisfied user of ParaSoft's Jtest and the JUnit f=
ramework and I would like to comment on some of your statements.

<snip>

>=
I have evaluated JTest version 4.5 and here are some JUnit related
>results=
:

Which version? I am using 4.5i and it is very good. Contact your ParaSof=
t representative to ensure that you have the latest and greatest version. P=
araSoft is very fast at fixing bugs and customer problem reports. (Well, th=
ey fix mine quickly! :-)

>1) JTest allows you to incorporate existing JUni=
t test with the JTest
>analysis

Correct. Isn't this wonderful! A commercia=
l company that recognises quality open-source software when they see it and=
 they made a decision to embrace it. I find this refreshing. Stay tuned for=
 further Junit related news. I am in regular communication with some of the=
 folks at ParaSoft and they are VERY forward thinking in regards of Junit a=
nd open-source in general.

>2) JTest can generate a JUnit template for par=
ticular classes, it
>doesn't go any further than this

This statement is te=
chnically correct but only tells half of the story. A unit test is supposed=
 to be written by a programmer/tester/human being. Jtest is an automated te=
sting tool. It cannot write business logic/customer requirement testing uni=
t tests! How is it supposed to know what your customers wanted? It generate=
s an initial Junit outline upon request, but they haven't built in the nece=
ssary ESP to read your customers minds yet.

For basic value objects (i.e. =
only getters and setters) it will actually generate very reasonable junit t=
ests. This is possible because it IS possible to test that a value is store=
d correctly and returned correctly without reading a customer's mind.

>3) =
Running JTest on junit.jar version 3.7 reports 24 runtime
>exceptions (see =
below)

This may be true. I've never tried it.

>4) Running JTest on Ant pr=
oduces 255 runtime exceptions

This may also be true. I've never tried this=
 either.

>5) You can't analyze JTest using JTest, it refuses to analyze
>"=
com.parasoft" packages (probably because you would find >>> 255
>errors)

A=
gain, I've never tried this. I can't say that I blame them though. It's a r=
ough old business world out there and you've got to take some precautions. =
Besides, they get enough "issue reports" from me to keep the bug count pret=
ty low! :-)

>All in all JUnit wise the support is somewhat disappointing t=
o me and

I'm very sorry that you don't like the facilities provided. I fin=
d them quite useful and acceptable. It's a free world. You are free to unin=
stall Jtest and take a chance on shipping untested, sub-optimal code and yo=
u are free to keep Jtest installed and have some of the squeakiest clean co=
de on the planet. I know which I'm gonna do.

>the 'Runtime Exception gener=
ator' facility is annoying.

Then don't run those tests. Jtest is configura=
ble and you can turn off tests that you deem inappropriate for you and your=
 situation. Our site does not use DbC, so we turn off all of the DbC tests.=
 Someday, we may get our developers using it, but until then it makes no se=
nse to test for compliance.

I have found that Jtest's attempts to call my =
code with strange and unusual runtime parameters has actually caused me to =
write better guard conditions, which makes my code much more robust. I appr=
eciate this behaviour from Jtest and have benefited greatly from it.


>Gre=
etings,
>A. Roy
>Java QA tester

And greetings to you, my fellow Jtest and =
Junit using developer.

>--- Junit 3.7 report -----
>All Errors Found - don=
e - 94 Errors Found
>        [ 24 ] Uncaught Runtime Exceptions
>
>        =
       [ 18 ] java.lang.NullPointerException
>
>               [ 1 ] java.l=
ang.StackOverflowError
>
>               [ 1 ] junit.framework.AssertionFai=
ledError
>
>               [ 1 ] java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException
=
>
>               [ 1 ] java.lang.ClassFormatError
>
>               [ 1 ] =
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
>
>               [ 1 ] java.lang.=
IllegalArgumentException

I would actually interpret these exceptions as an=
 indication of some extra guard conditions and more defensive programming n=
eeded within the tested code. If a piece of called code cannot handle unexp=
ected inputs, then the fault lies with the code and not the inputs. :-)

Ju=
st my $0.02

Simon
